name: Lorna S.
comment info:
I noticed that the majority of people would prefer to master skills that they thought would help them be more successful in life, whether it be through being able to communicate with more people (as shown by those who selected being able to speak three languages) or being able to cook for themselves. Far fewer individuals were interested in more creative skills, such as oil painting and gymnastics, hinting that they do not believe there is much to be gained from knowing how to do either of these activities. There does seem to be an overwhelming favor of more "white collar," higher paying jobs, as language fluency and neuroscience would both lead to higher salaries.

I wonder why these were the options. Oil painting seems like a very specific activity, compared to maybe just asking the students if they would want to master just painting. Also, I am curious to see if the students were searching for the "correct" answer or if maybe there was a bias in the polling, as different nationalities or classes might prioritize different skills. As those who participated were subscribers to the New York Times, they might be more interested in more academic activities verses those relating to art, physical education, or home maintenance.

These graph shows what skills high schoolers value, hinting on what classes they will take, degrees they will obtain, and eventually what the job market and the workforce will look like.

"A White Collar Future: America's Upcoming Workforce."

name: Moderator Kevin
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded!  We had so many great catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the map:  “Choose Your Skill. Become a Master" by Kaitlin of Massachusetts, “What Quarantine Skill Do You Want to Master?” by Molly of Salt Lake City, “Knock Down Barriers or Enhance Skills: What Would You Choose?” by Destiny of Providence, "Mastering Without Learning: Skills Readers Want Without Practicing" by Olivia of Wisconsin, “Language Fluency Over Gymnastics; Usefulness Over Hobby” by Annalee of Arcata, California, and “The Jack of All Trades Offers You One of His Skills" by Yomi of Minnesota.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back by Friday, Dec. 18 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the map, and a few Stat Nuggets.

Please visit our archive to see all graphs in this series (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphs) or a slide show of 60 of our favorite graphs (tinyurl.com/NYT60Graphs). 
View our archives that link to all past releases, organized by topic (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsTopicIndex), graph type (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsTypeIndex) and 
Stat Nugget (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsStatNuggetsIndex). 

Signing off – Sharon Hessney of Boston, who would love to become a gymnast without accidents and fear, and Kevin DeVizia of Millrift, Pennsylvania, who would love to be able to converse with anyone all over the world, all while developing his mad chef skills.

The graph is broken down into 100 dots to represent each percent of the 2,250 people surveyed. The remaining 40% are split between the following skills: neuroscience, oil painting, repairing any home appliance, and gymnastics. 

What do you wonder?
I wonder what was the primary demographic of people taking this survey. Were most over the age of 18? Were most living in areas with people of many cultures? Were many from urban cities? The answers to all these questions impact the results of the data. 

What impact does this have on you and your community?
This survey shows that the majority of people hope to learn new languages. This data can be used to impact my community because my classmates and I can help co-found a language club that helps expose people to several languages. 

Headline:
The Jack of All Trades Offers You One of His Skills: Which One Do You Choose?

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  

Today’s graph shows the responses of the New York Times’s research-and-analytics department survey of 2,250 subscribers who chose to participate.  They were asked in this voluntary online survey “Which would you choose to instantly master?

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and “What impact does this topic have on you?”

Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas in these graphs. 

By Friday morning, we’ll reveal the article that included this graph and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.

Note that you can get a link to your response to share with your teacher and classmates by clicking the response box below your response “Email me when my comment is published.”  

Please visit our archive to see all graphs in this series (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphs) or 
a slide show of 60 of our favorite graphs (tinyurl.com/NYT60Graphs).  
View our archives that link to all past releases, organized by topic (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsTopicIndex), 
graph type (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsTypeIndex) and 
Stat Nugget (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsStatNuggetsIndex).  

Keep noticing and wondering.  This is the last graph of 2020.  The next graph release will be by Friday, Jan. 1, 2021 with moderation on Wednesday, Jan. 6.  Stay tuned for which graph will be posted.

name: Paul Coffield
comment info:
I notice that this graph shows the responses of a survey. This survey gave participants a list of skills and asked them which skill they would choose to instantly master. The majority of people (60 percent) said that, out of the list of skills, being able to speak three languages is the most appealing. I wonder why the data is represented with circles. Does each circle represent a certain amount of people? If I could take this survey, I too would choose to instantly learn 3 languages of my choice because this seems to be the skill with the most practical applications. Many languages are disappearing as the world globalizes and English is quickly becoming a “universal language”. Learning different languages can not only make travel easier, but it can also help preserve disappearing languages that are important to certain cultures.
Catchy Headline: Interested in learning languages? You’re not alone.
Catchy Headline 2: Language is more appealing than neuroscience, NYT readers report
